results.title: Tyrants will rise from my tomb
results.creator_credit: Clive Fleury and Australian Broadcasting Commission
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Sweat of the sun, tears of the moon”.
The title of this episode is a quote from Simon Bolivar, the general who liberated South America from its Spanish conquerors over 150 years ago. Bolivar’s victory brought independence, but not necessarily freedom given the virtual epidemic of military dictatorships in South America since Bolivar. Writer and narrator, Jack Pizzey, visits two countries - Bolivia, named after Bolivar and Pinochet’s Chile - to discover why South Americans are prone to dictatorship and asks whether or not Bolivar’s nightmare of tyrants is fading.

results.title: Tyrannosaurus Rex
results.creator_credit: D. Keith Carlson and WGBH Educational Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Kindergarten child”
Children are shown working together on a project to reconstruct the land of dinosaurs, using papier-mache to create hills, trees, a moat, and some shallow water. They paint and classify toy models of dinosaurs.

results.creator_credit: Michael Law and Central Office of Information
results.brief_description: A number of common errors by typists illustrated and corrected in a humorous manner. The items covered include the taking of dictation, proper sitting posture when typing, general typing technique and care of the machine.

results.title: Typing skills: position and keystroke
results.creator_credit: Don B. Klugman, Creative Establishment and Coronet Films
results.brief_description: Janet Wilner’s company selected her for a time-mtion study and discovered that good typing starts with a typist’s position at the typewriter and with the way she manages her keystroke. Extensive slow-motion photography reveals the basic elements of good typing.

results.title: Typing skills: daily job techniques. - 2nd ed.

results.title: Typically British: Irish cinema: ourselves alone?
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Century of cinema”.
Typically British. Directed by Mike Dibb and Stephen Frears, produced by Colin MacCabe. Francois Truffaut once observed that the words ‘British’ and ‘cinema’ seemed incompatable. In his celebration of 100 years of British Cinema, Stephen Frears shapes an elegant and witty riposte to this statement. In discussion with other British film-makers, Frears explores the wealth of stylish and familiar images created by the British film industry over the last century. “Irish Cinema: Ourselves alone”. Produced and directed by Donald Taylor Black. Narrated by Gabriel Byrne, this documentary looks at the struggle of Irish people to create an Irish cinema. Carefully intercutting interviews with directors, writers and producers with clips from feature films, location footage and fascinating archive material, Donald Taylor Black compares past and present in order to ask questions about the future of Irish cinema.
